content: I want to show my gratitude to police, firemen and firewomen and EMTs. They get little recognition for the jobs they do. If you will recall, last month we had an intruder in our home. He did not cause any problems, the Sheriff was here in 5 minutes, they looked for him, but did not find him. A week ago Thursday, a woman sideswiped our car in the Wal Mart parking lot. Lora had got behind the steering a second or two before the woman hit our car. If she had been a second or two earlier...she would have seriously injured or killed Lora. State Patrol and city police were there in less than 10 minutes. The Fire Department, EMTs were there just behind the cops. The lady who struck our car had some medical emergency, EMTs assisted her. Keep smiling, everyone will wonder what you've been up to!
reply: I want to show my gratitude to police, firemen and firewomen and EMTs. They get little recognition for the jobs they do. If you will recall, last month we had an intruder in our home. He did not cause any problems, the Sheriff was here in 5 minutes, they looked for him, but did not find him. A week ago Thursday, a woman sideswiped our car in the Wal Mart parking lot. Lora had got behind the steering a second or two before the woman hit our car. If she had been a second or two earlier...she would have seriously injured or killed Lora. State Patrol and city police were there in less than 10 minutes. The Fire Department, EMTs were there just behind the cops. The lady who struck our car had some medical emergency, EMTs assisted her. Keep smiling, everyone will wonder what you've been up to!
title: A salute to Law Enforcement, Fire Departments and EMTs.

title: A salute to Law Enforcement, Fire Departments and EMTs.

content: I think being a State Trooper driving around in a high performance Camaro or Mustang with radar would be a blast and a job I would love. Of course I'd go easy on any combat veterans I'd catch speeding.
reply: I think being a State Trooper driving around in a high performance Camaro or Mustang with radar would be a blast and a job I would love. Of course I'd go easy on any combat veterans I'd catch speeding.
title: A salute to Law Enforcement, Fire Departments and EMTs.

content: quote: Originally posted by Duster6: I think being a State Trooper driving around in a high performance Camaro or Mustang with radar would be a blast and a job I would love. Of course I'd go easy on any combat veterans I'd catch speeding. It doesn't work that way. Everyone's supposed to be equal under the law. One of the biggest problems here in Fayetteville/Cumberland County, NC is that almost everyone knows, "someone." The cop writes the ticket and an hour later it's gone like a fart in the breeze. The cops lose their pride in their work and between that and the low pay, move on. The only people that they can find to work law enforcement are all too often those that wouldn't be hired elsewhere. Just last week a state representative was pulled over for speeding (110Mph.) and had alcohol on his breath. He was let off with a verbal warning. The only reason he was finally ticketed was that he was too stupid to keep his mouth shut and stay under the radar. He got to the state house still smelling of alcohol, Hugged and kissed a page, I think it was, and when chastised for his actions, told his colleges that if they didn't like it they could go to hell. How come I pressed "One for English" and still can't understand a word the dude is saying?
quote: Originally posted by Duster6: I think being a State Trooper driving around in a high performance Camaro or Mustang with radar would be a blast and a job I would love. Of course I'd go easy on any combat veterans I'd catch speeding.
reply: It doesn't work that way. Everyone's supposed to be equal under the law. One of the biggest problems here in Fayetteville/Cumberland County, NC is that almost everyone knows, "someone." The cop writes the ticket and an hour later it's gone like a fart in the breeze. The cops lose their pride in their work and between that and the low pay, move on. The only people that they can find to work law enforcement are all too often those that wouldn't be hired elsewhere. Just last week a state representative was pulled over for speeding (110Mph.) and had alcohol on his breath. He was let off with a verbal warning. The only reason he was finally ticketed was that he was too stupid to keep his mouth shut and stay under the radar. He got to the state house still smelling of alcohol, Hugged and kissed a page, I think it was, and when chastised for his actions, told his colleges that if they didn't like it they could go to hell. How come I pressed "One for English" and still can't understand a word the dude is saying?
title: A salute to Law Enforcement, Fire Departments and EMTs.

content: quote: Originally posted by scpd3045: I can't think of any closer comparison to police work as the military. Law Enforcement Officers, like the military: when the shooting starts and eveyone is running away, they run towards the shooting. Much like the firemen and EMT's: when everyone is running out of the burning building, they head into it. Last but not least, teachers....I use to visit my wife when she worked a daycare. Five minutes around all those screaming kids and I was ready to do some heavy drinking. OK, two more...doctors and nurses for all the work they do. Dr. J. Dean Cole, the surgeon who saved my leg back in '04. Don
quote: Originally posted by scpd3045: I can't think of any closer comparison to police work as the military.
reply: Law Enforcement Officers, like the military: when the shooting starts and eveyone is running away, they run towards the shooting. Five minutes around all those screaming kids and I was ready to do some heavy drinking. OK, two more...doctors and nurses for all the work they do. Dr. J. Dean Cole, the surgeon who saved my leg back in '04. Don
title: A salute to Law Enforcement, Fire Departments and EMTs.

content: Thanks Kevin, Lora and I will ever forget the young man who took control of the situation when our car was side swiped. He's a former military policeman, he's appying to the Boarder Patrol for an officer position! Lora and I are praying for he and his wife. We aree praying that he is hired by the Boader Patrol! Although he didn't say anything, Lora could tell that he and his wife were struggling finanicially. She sent him a check as a thank you! Keep smiling, everyone will wonder what you've been up to!
reply: Thanks Kevin, Lora and I will ever forget the young man who took control of the situation when our car was side swiped. content: Did ya know that an EMT/Paramedic/Flight Nurse must be in excellent physical shape. Gotta go down Ravines and such or climb a hill to reach the Trauma Victims. So, for me, can't do that anymore. Early Osteoporosis....GRRRRrrrr! And oh yeah, gotta have HAZMAT Certification too.

I thought when I left Fayettenam back in the 60's things cooled down a little. Guess not.
quote: Originally posted by Vicdude: quote: Originally posted by Duster6: I think being a State Trooper driving around in a high performance Camaro or Mustang with radar would be a blast and a job I would love. Of course I'd go easy on any combat veterans I'd catch speeding. It doesn't work that way. Everyone's supposed to be equal under the law. One of the biggest problems here in Fayetteville/Cumberland County, NC is that almost everyone knows, "someone." The cop writes the ticket and an hour later it's gone like a fart in the breeze. The cops lose their pride in their work and between that and the low pay, move on. The only people that they can find to work law enforcement are all too often those that wouldn't be hired elsewhere. Just last week a state representative was pulled over for speeding (110Mph.) and had alcohol on his breath. He was let off with a verbal warning. The only reason he was finally ticketed was that he was too stupid to keep his mouth shut and stay under the radar. He got to the state house still smelling of alcohol, Hugged and kissed a page, I think it was, and when chastised for his actions, told his colleges that if they didn't like it they could go to hell.
reply: I thought when I left Fayettenam back in the 60's things cooled down a little. Guess not.
title: A salute to Law Enforcement, Fire Departments and EMTs.

content: quote: Originally posted by 21yrsUSCGUSCS: quote: Originally posted by scpd3045: I can't think of any closer comparison to police work as the military. Law Enforcement Officers, like the military: when the shooting starts and eveyone is running away, they run towards the shooting. Much like the firemen and EMT's: when everyone is running out of the burning building, they head into it. Last but not least, teachers....I use to visit my wife when she worked a daycare. Five minutes around all those screaming kids and I was ready to do some heavy drinking. OK, two more...doctors and nurses for all the work they do. Dr. J. Dean Cole, the surgeon who saved my leg back in '04. Don Don! Thanks for the shout out for the Docs and Nurses! I am one of those Nurses! Appreciate it. Once again, THX Don. Signed Agent 99!
quote: Originally posted by 21yrsUSCGUSCS: quote: Originally posted by scpd3045: I can't think of any closer comparison to police work as the military. Law Enforcement Officers, like the military: when the shooting starts and eveyone is running away, they run towards the shooting. Much like the firemen and EMT's: when everyone is running out of the burning building, they head into it. Last but not least, teachers....I use to visit my wife when she worked a daycare. Five minutes around all those screaming kids and I was ready to do some heavy drinking. OK, two more...doctors and nurses for all the work they do. Dr. J. Dean Cole, the surgeon who saved my leg back in '04. Don
reply: Don! Thanks for the shout out for the Docs and Nurses! I am one of those Nurses! Appreciate it. Once again, THX Don. Signed Agent 99!
title: A salute to Law Enforcement, Fire Departments and EMTs.

content: quote: Originally posted by sargeant_green: Amen brother. I got a Nephew in the southern part of the State who is one of those flying EMT's. Mountain country, I pray for him all the time. SG! I'll pray for him too! I've done the Flight Nurse thing for Providence Hospital in Columbia,SC. Yep....a chopper went down. Me be RN,BSN,MSN but also a Paramedic;certified. Don't do the Flight Nurse anymore though. It is risky!
quote: Originally posted by sargeant_green: Amen brother. I got a Nephew in the southern part of the State who is one of those flying EMT's. Mountain country, I pray for him all the time.
reply: SG! I'll pray for him too! I've done the Flight Nurse thing for Providence Hospital in Columbia,SC. Yep....a chopper went down. Me be RN,BSN,MSN but also a Paramedic;certified. Don't do the Flight Nurse anymore though. It is risky!
title: A salute to Law Enforcement, Fire Departments and EMTs.

content: Did ya know that an EMT/Paramedic/Flight Nurse must be in excellent physical shape. Gotta go down Ravines and such or climb a hill to reach the Trauma Victims. So, for me, can't do that anymore. Early Osteoporosis....GRRRRrrrr! And oh yeah, gotta have HAZMAT Certification too.
reply: Did ya know that an EMT/Paramedic/Flight Nurse must be in excellent physical shape. Gotta go down Ravines and such or climb a hill to reach the Trauma Victims. So, for me, can't do that anymore. Early Osteoporosis....GRRRRrrrr! And oh yeah, gotta have HAZMAT Certification too.
title: A salute to Law Enforcement, Fire Departments and EMTs.
